docs.title: HCPI Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the HCPI (Harmonized Consumer Price Index) documentation. HCPI is a comprehensive system for collecting and analyzing price data, used by EAC Statistics bodies.

docs.title: What is HCPI?
docs.text:
HCPI is a Cost Price Index system built on Odoo 18 that enables statistical organizations to:

  • Collect price data efficiently
  • Analyze pricing trends
  • Generate statistical reports
  • Manage field data collection operations

docs.title: Live Demo
docs.text: You can explore a live instance of the Ugandan version at https://uboscpi.ubos.org/odoo

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
To get started with HCPI, follow these steps:

  1. Review the Prerequisites to ensure your system meets the requirements
  2. Choose your installation method:
  3. Linux Server Installation - Recommended for production
  4. Windows WSL Installation - Good for development
  5. Windows Native Installation - For testing (may have minor differences from production)

docs.title: System Overview
docs.text:
HCPI is built on Odoo 18 and consists of:

  • Custom HCPI Module: Contains the price index-specific functionality
  • Odoo Core: The underlying framework (Odoo 18)
  • PostgreSQL Database: For data storage
  • Python Virtual Environment: For dependency management

docs.title: Download Files
docs.text:
Installation files are available at: http://statistics.ubos.org/hcpishare

  • hcpi-files.zip: Contains the conf and custom folders with HCPI modules
  • hcpi-db.zip: Contains hcpi.sql PostgreSQL database dump (optional - only needed if you want sample data)

Empty Instance

You don't need to restore the database if you want to start with an empty HCPI instance. Odoo will initialize a fresh database for you.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: If you encounter issues during installation or usage, please refer to the specific installation guide for your platform or consult the Odoo 18 documentation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: HCPI (Harmonized Consumer Price Index) is a comprehensive system designed for statistical organizations to collect, manage, and analyze price data for consumer price index calculations.

docs.title: Built on Odoo 18
docs.text:
HCPI is built on top of Odoo 18, a powerful open-source business application platform. This provides HCPI with:

  • A robust framework for data management
  • User authentication and access control
  • Flexible reporting capabilities
  • Mobile-friendly interface
  • Extensive customization options

docs.title: Data Collection
docs.text:
• Streamlined price data entry
  • Support for field data collection operations
  • Mobile-responsive interface for on-the-go data entry

docs.title: Analysis & Reporting
docs.text:
• Price trend analysis
  • Statistical calculations
  • Customizable reports
  • Data visualization tools

docs.title: Multi-Organization Support
docs.text:
• Used by EAC Statistics bodies
  • Configurable for different organizational needs
  • Multi-user access with role-based permissions

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
The HCPI installation consists of the following components:

/opt/hcpi/
├── conf/          # Configuration files
├── custom/        # Custom modules including HCPI
│   └── HCPI/      # Main HCPI module
├── log/           # Application logs
├── odoo/          # Odoo 18 core codebase
└── venv/          # Python virtual environment

docs.title: Technical Stack
docs.text:
• Backend: Python 3.10+
  • Framework: Odoo 18
  • Database: PostgreSQL 12+
  • Frontend: Web-based (HTML, JavaScript, CSS)
  • Reporting: wkhtmltopdf for PDF generation

docs.title: Live Example
docs.text:
A live deployment of HCPI can be accessed at: https://uboscpi.ubos.org/odoo

This is the Ugandan version managed by UBOS (Uganda Bureau of Statistics).

docs.title: Download Files
docs.text:
Installation files are available at: http://statistics.ubos.org/hcpishare

  • hcpi-code.zip: Complete HCPI application code
  • hcpi-sql.zip: Sample PostgreSQL database

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
HCPI is designed for:

  • National statistics offices
  • Regional statistical organizations
  • Research institutions studying price trends
  • Economic analysis organizations

docs.title: Support & Resources
docs.text:
• Odoo Documentation: https://www.odoo.com/documentation/18.0/
  • Installation Guides: See the Installation section in this documentation
  • Getting Started: Review the Prerequisites page

docs.title: License
docs.text: HCPI is built on Odoo, which is available under the LGPL v3 license. Please refer to the Odoo documentation for specific licensing details.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Before installing HCPI, ensure your system meets the following requirements.

docs.title: For Linux and Windows WSL
docs.text:
• Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04 LTS or later (or compatible Linux distribution)
  • RAM: Minimum 4GB (8GB recommended for production)
  • Disk Space: At least 10GB free space
  • User Privileges: Sudo access for package installation

docs.title: For Windows Native
docs.text:
• Operating System: Windows 10 or Windows Server 2016 or later
  • RAM: Minimum 4GB (8GB recommended)
  • Disk Space: At least 10GB free space

Production Deployment

Windows native installation is suitable for testing and development. For production deployments, use Linux or Windows WSL for better compatibility and performance.

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
• Version: Python 3.10 or later
  • Used for running Odoo and HCPI modules

docs.title: PostgreSQL
docs.text:
• Version: PostgreSQL 12 or later
  • The database backend for HCPI

docs.title: Additional Tools
docs.text:
The following will be installed during the setup process:

  • Git (for version control)
  • pip (Python package manager)
  • virtualenv (for Python virtual environment management)
  • wkhtmltopdf (for PDF report generation)

docs.title: Download Required Files
docs.text:
Before starting installation, download the required files from: http://statistics.ubos.org/hcpishare

  1. hcpi-code.zip - Contains the HCPI application code
  2. hcpi-sql.zip - Contains the PostgreSQL database dump (optional)

Database Restore

Only download and restore hcpi-sql.zip if you want to start with sample data. You can skip this for a fresh, empty instance.

docs.title: Knowledge Prerequisites
docs.text:
This documentation assumes you have:

  • Basic command-line familiarity
  • Basic understanding of Python environments
  • Basic Linux/Unix command knowledge (for Linux and WSL installations)

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Once you've confirmed your system meets these requirements and downloaded the necessary files, proceed to the installation guide for your platform:

  • Linux Server Installation
  • Windows WSL Installation
  • Windows Native Installation

docs.title: Linux Server Installation
docs.text: This guide walks you through installing HCPI on a Linux server (Ubuntu 20.04 LTS or later recommended).

docs.title: Step 1: Update System Packages
docs.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade -y

docs.title: Step 2: Install System Dependencies
docs.text:
Install required packages:

sudo apt install -y git python3 python3-pip python3-dev python3-venv \
    postgresql postgresql-contrib libpq-dev \
    build-essential libssl-dev libffi-dev libxml2-dev libxslt1-dev \
    zlib1g-dev libjpeg-dev libsasl2-dev libldap2-dev \
    node-less npm wkhtmltopdf unzip

docs.title: Step 3: Configure PostgreSQL
docs.text:
Create a PostgreSQL user and database for HCPI:

sudo -u postgres createuser -s hcpi
sudo -u postgres psql -c "ALTER USER hcpi WITH PASSWORD 'your_secure_password';"
sudo -u postgres createdb -O hcpi hcpi

Database User

We're using hcpi as both the database name and username. You can choose different names, but make sure to update the configuration file accordingly.

docs.title: Step 4: Create Directory Structure
docs.text:
Create the HCPI directory structure:

sudo mkdir -p /opt/hcpi
sudo chown $USER:$USER /opt/hcpi
cd /opt/hcpi

Custom Installation Path

If you choose a different path than /opt/hcpi, you'll need to update the paths in the configuration file (see Step 7).

docs.title: Step 5: Download and Set Up HCPI Files
docs.text:
Download the files from http://statistics.ubos.org/hcpishare and set up the directory structure:

cd /opt/hcpi

# Extract HCPI files (contains conf and custom folders)
unzip hcpi-files.zip

# Clone Odoo 18
git clone --depth 1 --branch 18.0 https://github.com/odoo/odoo.git

# Create log directory
mkdir -p log

After this, you should have:

/opt/hcpi/
├── conf/          # Configuration files (from hcpi-files.zip)
├── custom/        # Contains HCPI module (from hcpi-files.zip)
│   └── HCPI/      # Main HCPI module
├── log/           # Log files (created)
├── odoo/          # Odoo 18 codebase (cloned)
└── venv/          # Python virtual environment (will create next)

docs.title: Step 6: Set Up Python Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Create and activate the virtual environment:

cd /opt/hcpi
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate

Install Python dependencies:

pip install --upgrade pip
pip install wheel
pip install numpy
pip install -r odoo/requirements.txt

NumPy Requirement

NumPy is required for HCPI but not included in Odoo's default requirements, so we install it separately.

docs.title: Step 7: Configure Odoo
docs.text:
The configuration file is already provided in /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf. Review and update the following settings:

nano /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf

Key settings to update:

[options]
; Change this to a strong password for database management operations
admin_passwd = your_strong_admin_password

; Set this to match the PostgreSQL password from Step 3
db_password = your_secure_password

; UPDATE THESE PATHS if you installed to a different location than /opt/hcpi
addons_path = /opt/hcpi/odoo/addons,/opt/hcpi/custom/HCPI
logfile = /opt/hcpi/log/hcpi.log

; Change this if port 9201 is already in use
http_port = 9201

Important

  • admin_passwd: Used for database management operations - choose a strong password
  • db_password: Must match the PostgreSQL password you created in Step 3
  • Paths: Update addons_path and logfile if you chose a different installation location
  • http_port: Change if port 9201 is already in use

docs.title: Option A: Start with Sample Data
docs.text:
If you want to work with existing data, restore the database:

cd /opt/hcpi
unzip hcpi-db.zip
psql -U hcpi -d hcpi -f hcpi.sql

Enter the hcpi user password when prompted.

docs.title: Option B: Start with Empty Instance
docs.text:
If you want a fresh HCPI instance with just the modules:

Simply skip this step. Odoo will initialize the database when you first run it with the -i HCPI flag (see Step 9).

docs.title: Step 9: Start HCPI
docs.text:
Start Odoo with the HCPI configuration:

cd /opt/hcpi
source venv/bin/activate
python odoo/odoo-bin -c conf/hcpi.conf

First Run with Empty Database

If you didn't restore a database, use this command on first run to install the HCPI module and generate assets: 

python odoo/odoo-bin -c conf/hcpi.conf -u all --dev=all
This ensures icons and assets are properly generated on the first run.

First-Time Startup

The first time you start HCPI, it may take a few minutes to initialize. Be patient during the initial load. Subsequent starts will be much faster.

docs.title: Step 10: Configure Firewall
docs.text:
Allow access to the HCPI port (default 9201):

sudo ufw allow 9201/tcp

docs.title: Step 11: Access HCPI
docs.text:
Open your web browser and navigate to:

http://localhost:9201

Or if accessing remotely:

http://your_server_ip:9201

First Load May Be Slow

The first time you access HCPI, the page may take 30-60 seconds to load as it initializes the interface. After this initial load, performance should be normal.

docs.title: Fix Missing Icons
docs.text:
If you notice missing icons in the interface after installation:

Before (missing icons):

To fix:

  1. Click on your username in the top right
  2. Go to Settings → Activate the developer mode
  3. Then go to Settings → Technical → User Interface → Regenerate Assets Bundles
  4. Refresh the page

After (icons restored):

Alternatively, you can restart HCPI with the asset regeneration flag:

python odoo/odoo-bin -c conf/hcpi.conf -u all --dev=all

docs.title: Running as a Service (Recommended for Production)
docs.text:
Create a systemd service file for automatic startup:

sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/hcpi.service

Add the following content (update paths if you used a different location):

[Unit]
Description=HCPI Odoo Service
After=network.target postgresql.service

[Service]
Type=simple
User=your_username
Group=your_username
WorkingDirectory=/opt/hcpi
Environment="PATH=/opt/hcpi/venv/bin"
ExecStart=/opt/hcpi/venv/bin/python /opt/hcpi/odoo/odoo-bin -c /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=10

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Replace your_username with your actual username, then enable and start the service:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable hcpi
sudo systemctl start hcpi

Check service status:

sudo systemctl status hcpi

docs.title: Check Logs
docs.text:
View HCPI logs:

tail -f /opt/hcpi/log/hcpi.log

docs.title: Service Issues
docs.text:
If the service fails to start:

sudo systemctl status hcpi
sudo journalctl -u hcpi -n 50

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If port 9201 is already in use, change it in /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf:

http_port = 9202

Then restart the service or HCPI.

docs.title: Database Connection Issues
docs.text:
If you get database connection errors, verify:

# Check PostgreSQL is running
sudo systemctl status postgresql

# Test database connection
psql -U hcpi -d hcpi -c "SELECT version();"

docs.title: Module Not Found
docs.text:
If HCPI module is not found, verify the addons_path in the config file points to the correct location:

addons_path = /opt/hcpi/odoo/addons,/opt/hcpi/custom/HCPI

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Set up SSL/TLS with nginx or Apache as a reverse proxy
  • Configure regular database backups
  • Review the Odoo 18 documentation for advanced configuration
  • Configure user accounts and permissions in HCPI

docs.title: Windows Native Installation
docs.text:
This guide covers installing HCPI directly on Windows without WSL.

Limited Development Suitability

Windows native installation has significant limitations even for development work. Due to path handling differences and platform-specific behaviors, some features may not work as expected. Even for development and testing, Windows WSL is strongly recommended as it provides a Linux environment with better compatibility. For production deployments, always use Linux.

Use Windows native installation only if WSL is not available on your system.

docs.title: Step 1: Enable PowerShell Script Execution
docs.text:
Before installing Python, enable PowerShell to run scripts. Open PowerShell as Administrator and run:

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

This allows you to run local scripts, which is needed for some installation steps.

docs.title: Step 2: Install Python
docs.text:
Python Version Requirement

HCPI works best with Python 3.10, 3.11, or 3.12. Python 3.13+ may have compatibility issues with some Odoo dependencies.

docs.title: Check Current Python Version
docs.text:
First, check if you have Python installed:

python --version

docs.title: If Python 3.13+ is Installed (or No Python)
docs.text:
Click here if you have Python 3.13+ or need to install Python 3.12 If you have Python 3.13 or later, use pyenv-win to install Python 3.12: **Install pyenv-win:** 
Invoke-WebRequest -UseBasicParsing -Uri "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pyenv-win/pyenv-win/master/pyenv-win/install-pyenv-win.ps1" -OutFile "./install-pyenv-win.ps1"
./install-pyenv-win.ps1
Close and reopen PowerShell, then install Python 3.12: 
pyenv install 3.12.8
pyenv global 3.12.8
Verify the version: 
python --version

docs.title: If Installing Python Fresh
docs.text:
Download and install Python 3.12.x from python.org:

  1. Download the Python 3.12.x Windows installer
  2. Important: Check "Add Python to PATH" during installation
  3. Complete the installation

Verify installation:

python --version
pip --version

docs.title: Step 3: Install PostgreSQL
docs.text:
Download and install PostgreSQL from postgresql.org:

  1. Download the Windows installer (version 12 or later)
  2. During installation:
  3. Remember the password you set for the postgres user
  4. Default port is 5432 (keep this unless you have conflicts)
  5. Install pgAdmin 4 (helpful for database management)
  6. Complete the installation

Add PostgreSQL to your PATH: 1. Open System Properties → Environment Variables 2. Edit Path variable 3. Add: C:\Program Files\PostgreSQL\15\bin (adjust version number as needed)

docs.title: Step 4: Install Git
docs.text:
Download and install Git from git-scm.com:

  1. Download and run the installer
  2. Use default options during installation

docs.title: Step 5: Install wkhtmltopdf
docs.text:
Download and install wkhtmltopdf from wkhtmltopdf.org:

  1. Download the Windows installer
  2. Install to default location
  3. Add to PATH: C:\Program Files\wkhtmltopdf\bin

docs.title: Step 6: Set Up PostgreSQL Database
docs.text:
Open Command Prompt as Administrator and create user and database:

psql -U postgres

Enter the postgres password you set during installation. Then in the PostgreSQL prompt:

CREATE USER hcpi WITH PASSWORD 'your_secure_password';
CREATE DATABASE hcpi OWNER hcpi;
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON DATABASE hcpi TO hcpi;
\q

Database User

We're using hcpi as both the database name and username. You can choose different names, but update the configuration file accordingly.

docs.title: Step 7: Create Directory Structure
docs.text:
Open Command Prompt or PowerShell and create the directory:

Command Prompt: 

mkdir C:\hcpi
cd C:\hcpi

PowerShell: 

New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path C:\hcpi
Set-Location C:\hcpi

Custom Installation Path

If you choose a different path than C:\hcpi, you'll need to update the paths in the configuration file (see Step 8).

Alternative Location

While the Linux version uses /opt/hcpi, on Windows we use C:\hcpi for simplicity. You can choose a different location if preferred.

docs.title: Step 8: Download and Set Up HCPI Files
docs.text:
Download files from http://statistics.ubos.org/hcpishare and set up:

  1. Download hcpi-files.zip
  2. Extract contents to C:\hcpi

Clone Odoo 18 and create log directory:

Command Prompt: 

cd C:\hcpi
git clone --depth 1 --branch 18.0 https://github.com/odoo/odoo.git
mkdir log

PowerShell: 

Set-Location C:\hcpi
git clone --depth 1 --branch 18.0 https://github.com/odoo/odoo.git
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path log

You should now have:

C:\hcpi\
├── conf\          # Configuration files (from hcpi-files.zip)
├── custom\        # Contains HCPI module (from hcpi-files.zip)
│   └── HCPI\      # Main HCPI module
├── log\           # Log files (created)
├── odoo\          # Odoo 18 codebase (cloned)
└── venv\          # Python virtual environment (will create next)

docs.title: Step 9: Set Up Python Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Open Command Prompt in C:\hcpi:

cd C:\hcpi
python -m venv venv
venv\Scripts\activate

Your prompt should now show (venv).

Install dependencies:

python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install wheel
pip install numpy
pip install -r odoo\requirements.txt

Installation Issues

If you encounter errors installing some packages, you may need to install Visual C++ Build Tools from Microsoft.

NumPy Requirement

NumPy is required for HCPI but not included in Odoo's default requirements, so we install it separately.

docs.title: Step 10: Configure Odoo
docs.text:
The configuration file is already provided in C:\hcpi\conf\hcpi.conf. Review and update the following settings:

Edit with a text editor (Notepad, VS Code, etc.) and adjust these key settings:

Key settings to update:

[options]
; Change this to a strong password for database management operations
admin_passwd = your_strong_admin_password

; Windows requires explicit host
db_host = localhost
db_port = 5432

; Set this to match the PostgreSQL password from Step 5
db_password = your_secure_password

; UPDATE THESE PATHS if you installed to a different location - use backslashes (\)
addons_path = C:\hcpi\odoo\addons,C:\hcpi\custom\HCPI
logfile = C:\hcpi\log\hcpi.log

; Change this if port 9201 is already in use
http_port = 9201

Important Windows-Specific Settings

  • admin_passwd: Used for database management operations - choose a strong password
  • db_password: Must match the PostgreSQL password you created in Step 5
  • db_host: Must be localhost on Windows (unlike Linux where it can be False)
  • Paths: Must use backslashes (\), not forward slashes (/)
  • Paths location: Update addons_path and logfile if you chose a different installation location
  • http_port: Change if port 9201 is already in use

docs.title: Option A: Start with Sample Data
docs.text:
If you want to start with existing data:

  1. Download and extract hcpi-db.zip
  2. Open Command Prompt or PowerShell and run:

Command Prompt: 

psql -U hcpi -d hcpi -v ON_ERROR_STOP=0 -f path\to\hcpi.sql 2> restore_errors.log

PowerShell: 

psql -U hcpi -d hcpi -v ON_ERROR_STOP=0 -f path\to\hcpi.sql 2> restore_errors.log

Enter the hcpi user password when prompted.

Windows Restore Issues

The -v ON_ERROR_STOP=0 flag prevents the restore from stopping on minor errors (common when restoring Linux dumps on Windows). Errors are logged to restore_errors.log for review. Most errors related to permissions or Linux-specific features can be safely ignored.

docs.title: Option B: Start with Empty Instance
docs.text: Simply skip this step. Odoo will initialize the database when you first run it with the -i HCPI flag (see Step 12).

docs.title: Step 12: Start HCPI
docs.text:
Open Command Prompt in C:\hcpi:

cd C:\hcpi
venv\Scripts\activate
python odoo\odoo-bin -c conf\hcpi.conf

For first-time setup with empty database:

python odoo\odoo-bin -c conf\hcpi.conf -u all --dev=all

This ensures icons and assets are properly generated on the first run.

First-Time Startup

The first time you start HCPI, it may take a few minutes to initialize. Be patient during the initial load. Subsequent starts will be much faster.

docs.title: Step 13: Access HCPI
docs.text:
Open your web browser and navigate to:

http://localhost:9201

Or if you changed the port in the configuration, use that port instead.

Checking the Port

If you're unsure which port HCPI is running on, check the configuration file or look for a line in the logs that says "HTTP service (werkzeug) running on..."

First Load May Be Slow

The first time you access HCPI, the page may take 30-60 seconds to load as it initializes the interface. After this initial load, performance should be normal.

docs.title: Fix Missing Icons
docs.text:
If you notice missing icons in the interface after installation:

Before (missing icons):

To fix:

  1. Click on your username in the top right
  2. Go to Settings → Activate the developer mode
  3. Then go to Settings → Technical → User Interface → Regenerate Assets Bundles
  4. Refresh the page

After (icons restored):

Alternatively, you can restart HCPI with the asset regeneration flag:

python odoo\odoo-bin -c conf\hcpi.conf -u all --dev=all

docs.title: Creating a Startup Batch File
docs.text:
Create C:\hcpi\start-hcpi.bat:

@echo off
cd C:\hcpi
call venv\Scripts\activate
python odoo\odoo-bin -c conf\hcpi.conf
pause

Now you can double-click this file to start HCPI.

docs.title: Running as a Windows Service (Advanced)
docs.text:
For production-like setup, you can run HCPI as a Windows service using NSSM (Non-Sucking Service Manager):

  1. Download NSSM from nssm.cc
  2. Extract and open Command Prompt as Administrator
  3. Navigate to NSSM directory
  4. Run:
nssm install HCPI

Configure: - Path: C:\hcpi\venv\Scripts\python.exe - Startup directory: C:\hcpi - Arguments: odoo\odoo-bin -c conf\hcpi.conf

docs.title: Python Not Found
docs.text:
Ensure Python is in your PATH: 

where python

docs.title: PostgreSQL Connection Errors
docs.text: Check if PostgreSQL service is running: - Open Services (Win+R → services.msc) - Find "postgresql-x64-15" (version may vary) - Ensure it's running

docs.title: Database Connection Failed
docs.text: Make sure db_host is set to localhost in the config file (not False like in Linux).

docs.title: Module Import Errors
docs.text:
Ensure virtual environment is activated: 

venv\Scripts\activate

docs.title: Port 9201 Already in Use
docs.text:
Change the port in conf\hcpi.conf: 

http_port = 9202

docs.title: Check Logs
docs.text: Open C:\hcpi\log\hcpi.log in a text editor to see error messages.

docs.title: Module Not Found
docs.text:
Verify the addons_path in the config file uses Windows paths:

addons_path = C:\hcpi\odoo\addons,C:\hcpi\custom\HCPI

docs.title: Antivirus Interference
docs.text: Some antivirus software may block Odoo. Add C:\hcpi to your antivirus exclusions if you experience issues.

docs.title: Path Issues
docs.text: Make sure all paths in hcpi.conf use backslashes (\), not forward slashes (/).

docs.title: Known Limitations on Windows
docs.text:
• Some Odoo modules may have compatibility issues with Windows
  • Performance may be lower compared to Linux
  • File path handling differences may cause minor issues
  • Some system-level features may not work identically to Linux

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Review the Odoo 18 documentation
  • For a more production-like environment, consider using Windows WSL
  • Configure HCPI modules for your needs
  • Set up regular database backups using pgAdmin or command-line tools
  • Configure user accounts and permissions in HCPI

docs.title: Windows WSL Installation
docs.text:
This guide shows you how to install HCPI on Windows using WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux). This setup provides a Linux environment on Windows and is recommended for development work.

What is WSL?

WSL allows you to run a Linux distribution alongside your Windows installation. This provides better compatibility with Odoo and HCPI compared to native Windows installation.

docs.title: Step 1: Install WSL
docs.text:
Open PowerShell as Administrator and run:

wsl --install

This installs WSL with Ubuntu by default. Restart your computer when prompted.

Existing WSL Installation

If you already have WSL installed, you can install Ubuntu with: 

wsl --install -d Ubuntu

docs.title: Step 2: Set Up Ubuntu
docs.text:
After restart, Ubuntu will open automatically. Create your Linux username and password when prompted.

Remember Your Password

You'll need this password for sudo commands. Make sure to remember it!

docs.title: Step 3: Update Ubuntu Packages
docs.text:
In your Ubuntu terminal:

sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade -y

docs.title: Step 4: Install System Dependencies
docs.text:
Install required packages:

sudo apt install -y git python3 python3-pip python3-dev python3-venv \
    postgresql postgresql-contrib libpq-dev \
    build-essential libssl-dev libffi-dev libxml2-dev libxslt1-dev \
    zlib1g-dev libjpeg-dev libsasl2-dev libldap2-dev \
    node-less npm wkhtmltopdf unzip

docs.title: Step 5: Configure PostgreSQL
docs.text:
Start PostgreSQL service:

sudo service postgresql start

Create a PostgreSQL user and database:

sudo -u postgres createuser -s hcpi
sudo -u postgres psql -c "ALTER USER hcpi WITH PASSWORD 'your_secure_password';"
sudo -u postgres createdb -O hcpi hcpi

Database User

We're using hcpi as both the database name and username. You can choose different names, but update the configuration file accordingly.

Auto-start PostgreSQL

PostgreSQL doesn't auto-start in WSL. You'll need to run sudo service postgresql start each time you open WSL, or add it to your .bashrc: 

echo "sudo service postgresql start" >> ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Step 6: Create Directory Structure
docs.text:
Create the HCPI directory:

sudo mkdir -p /opt/hcpi
sudo chown $USER:$USER /opt/hcpi
cd /opt/hcpi

Custom Installation Path

If you choose a different path than /opt/hcpi, you'll need to update the paths in the configuration file (see Step 8).

docs.title: Step 7: Transfer and Set Up Files
Option A: Access Windows Files from WSL
docs.text:
Your Windows drives are accessible at /mnt/c/, /mnt/d/, etc.

If you've downloaded the files to your Windows Downloads folder:

cd /opt/hcpi

# Copy and extract HCPI files (contains conf and custom folders)
cp /mnt/c/Users/YourWindowsUsername/Downloads/hcpi-files.zip .
unzip hcpi-files.zip

# Clone Odoo 18
git clone --depth 1 --branch 18.0 https://github.com/odoo/odoo.git

# Create log directory
mkdir -p log

docs.title: Option B: Download Directly in WSL
docs.text:
If you can access the files via URL:

cd /opt/hcpi

# Download and extract HCPI files
wget http://statistics.ubos.org/hcpishare/hcpi-files.zip
unzip hcpi-files.zip

# Clone Odoo 18
git clone --depth 1 --branch 18.0 https://github.com/odoo/odoo.git

# Create log directory
mkdir -p log

After this, you should have:

/opt/hcpi/
├── conf/          # Configuration files (from hcpi-files.zip)
├── custom/        # Contains HCPI module (from hcpi-files.zip)
│   └── HCPI/      # Main HCPI module
├── log/           # Log files (created)
├── odoo/          # Odoo 18 codebase (cloned)
└── venv/          # Python virtual environment (will create next)

docs.title: Step 8: Set Up Python Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Create and activate the virtual environment:

cd /opt/hcpi
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate

Install Python dependencies:

pip install --upgrade pip
pip install wheel
pip install numpy
pip install -r odoo/requirements.txt

NumPy Requirement

NumPy is required for HCPI but not included in Odoo's default requirements, so we install it separately.

docs.title: Step 9: Configure Odoo
docs.text:
The configuration file is already provided in /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf. Review and update the following settings:

nano /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf

Key settings to update:

[options]
; Change this to a strong password for database management operations
admin_passwd = your_strong_admin_password

; Set this to match the PostgreSQL password from Step 5
db_password = your_secure_password

; UPDATE THESE PATHS if you installed to a different location than /opt/hcpi
addons_path = /opt/hcpi/odoo/addons,/opt/hcpi/custom/HCPI
logfile = /opt/hcpi/log/hcpi.log

; Change this if port 9201 is already in use
http_port = 9201

Important

  • admin_passwd: Used for database management operations - choose a strong password
  • db_password: Must match the PostgreSQL password you created in Step 5
  • Paths: Update addons_path and logfile if you chose a different installation location
  • http_port: Change if port 9201 is already in use

Save in Nano

Press Ctrl+X, then Y, then Enter to save and exit nano.

docs.title: Option A: Start with Sample Data
docs.text:
If you want to work with existing data:

cd /opt/hcpi
cp /mnt/c/Users/YourWindowsUsername/Downloads/hcpi-db.zip .
unzip hcpi-db.zip
psql -U hcpi -d hcpi -f hcpi.sql

Enter the hcpi user password when prompted.

docs.title: Option B: Start with Empty Instance
docs.text: Simply skip this step. Odoo will initialize the database when you first run it with the -i HCPI flag (see Step 11).

docs.title: Step 11: Start HCPI
docs.text:
Make sure PostgreSQL is running:

sudo service postgresql start

Start HCPI:

cd /opt/hcpi
source venv/bin/activate
python odoo/odoo-bin -c conf/hcpi.conf

For first-time setup with empty database:

python odoo/odoo-bin -c conf/hcpi.conf -u all --dev=all

This ensures icons and assets are properly generated on the first run.

First-Time Startup

The first time you start HCPI, it may take a few minutes to initialize. Be patient during the initial load. Subsequent starts will be much faster.

docs.title: Step 12: Access HCPI
docs.text:
Open your Windows web browser and navigate to:

http://localhost:9201

First Load May Be Slow

The first time you access HCPI, the page may take 30-60 seconds to load as it initializes the interface. After this initial load, performance should be normal.

docs.title: Fix Missing Icons
docs.text:
If you notice missing icons in the interface after installation:

Before (missing icons):

To fix:

  1. Click on your username in the top right
  2. Go to Settings → Activate the developer mode
  3. Then go to Settings → Technical → User Interface → Regenerate Assets Bundles
  4. Refresh the page

After (icons restored):

Alternatively, you can restart HCPI with the asset regeneration flag:

python odoo/odoo-bin -c conf/hcpi.conf -u all --dev=all

docs.title: Creating a Startup Script (Optional)
docs.text:
Create a convenient startup script:

nano ~/start-hcpi.sh

Add:

#!/bin/bash
sudo service postgresql start
cd /opt/hcpi
source venv/bin/activate
python odoo/odoo-bin -c conf/hcpi.conf

Make it executable:

chmod +x ~/start-hcpi.sh

Now you can start HCPI with:

~/start-hcpi.sh

docs.title: Accessing Files Between Windows and WSL
From WSL to Windows
docs.text: Windows drives are mounted at /mnt/: - C: drive → /mnt/c/ - D: drive → /mnt/d/

docs.title: From Windows to WSL
docs.text:
Open File Explorer and enter in the address bar: 

\\wsl$\Ubuntu\opt\hcpi

docs.title: PostgreSQL Won't Start
docs.text:
sudo service postgresql status
sudo service postgresql restart

docs.title: Database Connection Issues
docs.text:
Test the database connection:

psql -U hcpi -d hcpi -c "SELECT version();"

docs.title: Permission Issues
docs.text:
If you get permission errors:

sudo chown -R $USER:$USER /opt/hcpi

docs.title: Python Module Errors
docs.text:
Ensure you're in the virtual environment:

source /opt/hcpi/venv/bin/activate

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
Change the port in /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf:

http_port = 9202

docs.title: Module Not Found
docs.text:
Verify the addons_path in the config file:

addons_path = /opt/hcpi/odoo/addons,/opt/hcpi/custom/HCPI

docs.title: Check Logs
docs.text: tail -f /opt/hcpi/log/hcpi.log

docs.title: Performance Tips
docs.text:
• Place project files in the Linux filesystem (/opt/hcpi) rather than accessing Windows filesystem (/mnt/c/) for better performance
  • Allocate more RAM to WSL if needed by creating .wslconfig in your Windows user directory

docs.text: After successfully installing HCPI, here are the recommended next steps to secure, optimize, and prepare your installation for production use.

docs.title: HTTPS Setup with Nginx
docs.text:
This guide shows you how to set up a secure HTTPS connection for HCPI using Nginx as a reverse proxy with SSL/TLS certificates.

For Production Only

This guide is intended for production Linux servers. Development environments typically don't require HTTPS setup.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• HCPI installed and running on a Linux server
  • A domain name pointing to your server's IP address
  • Root or sudo access to the server
  • Ports 80 and 443 open in your firewall

docs.title: Step 1: Install Nginx
docs.text:
Install Nginx on your Ubuntu server:

sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y nginx

Verify Nginx is running:

sudo systemctl status nginx

docs.title: Step 2: Install Certbot for SSL Certificates
docs.text:
Install Certbot to obtain free SSL certificates from Let's Encrypt:

sudo apt install -y certbot python3-certbot-nginx

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Nginx for HCPI
docs.text:
Create a new Nginx configuration file for HCPI:

sudo nano /etc/nginx/sites-available/hcpi

Add the following configuration (replace your-domain.com with your actual domain):

# HTTP server - redirects to HTTPS
server {
    listen 80;
    server_name your-domain.com www.your-domain.com;

    # Redirect all HTTP traffic to HTTPS
    return 301 https://$server_name$request_uri;
}

# HTTPS server
server {
    listen 443 ssl http2;
    server_name your-domain.com www.your-domain.com;

    # SSL certificate paths (will be configured by Certbot)
    ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/your-domain.com/fullchain.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/your-domain.com/privkey.pem;

    # SSL configuration
    ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3;
    ssl_ciphers HIGH:!aNULL:!MD5;
    ssl_prefer_server_ciphers on;

    # Security headers
    add_header Strict-Transport-Security "max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains" always;
    add_header X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN" always;
    add_header X-Content-Type-Options "nosniff" always;

    # Logging
    access_log /var/log/nginx/hcpi_access.log;
    error_log /var/log/nginx/hcpi_error.log;

    # Proxy settings
    location / {
        proxy_pass http://127.0.0.1:9201;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;

        # WebSocket support
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade";

        # Timeouts
        proxy_connect_timeout 600;
        proxy_send_timeout 600;
        proxy_read_timeout 600;
        send_timeout 600;
    }

    # Increase client max body size for file uploads
    client_max_body_size 100M;
}

Update Domain Name

Replace your-domain.com with your actual domain name throughout the configuration file.

docs.title: Step 4: Enable the Configuration
docs.text:
Create a symbolic link to enable the site:

sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/hcpi /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/

Remove the default Nginx site if it exists:

sudo rm /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/default

Test the Nginx configuration:

sudo nginx -t

docs.title: Step 5: Obtain SSL Certificate
docs.text:
Use Certbot to obtain and install an SSL certificate:

sudo certbot --nginx -d your-domain.com -d www.your-domain.com

Follow the prompts: - Enter your email address - Agree to the terms of service - Choose whether to redirect HTTP to HTTPS (recommended: Yes)

Certbot will automatically: - Obtain the SSL certificate - Configure Nginx to use it - Set up automatic renewal

docs.title: Step 6: Configure Firewall
docs.text:
Allow HTTP and HTTPS traffic through the firewall:

sudo ufw allow 'Nginx Full'
sudo ufw delete allow 9201

This allows ports 80 and 443, and removes direct access to port 9201.

docs.title: Step 7: Restart Services
docs.text:
Restart Nginx to apply changes:

sudo systemctl restart nginx

Ensure HCPI is running:

sudo systemctl status hcpi

docs.title: Step 8: Test Your Setup
docs.text:
Visit your domain in a web browser:

https://your-domain.com

You should see: - A secure padlock icon in the browser - HCPI login page - Valid SSL certificate

docs.title: Step 9: Configure Auto-Renewal
docs.text:
Certbot automatically sets up certificate renewal. Test the renewal process:

sudo certbot renew --dry-run

If successful, your certificates will automatically renew before expiration.

docs.title: Update HCPI Configuration (Optional)
docs.text:
You can configure HCPI to only listen on localhost since Nginx will handle external connections:

Edit /opt/hcpi/conf/hcpi.conf:

[options]
# ... other settings ...
http_interface = 127.0.0.1
http_port = 9201

Restart HCPI:

sudo systemctl restart hcpi

docs.title: Nginx Won't Start
docs.text:
Check the error log: 

sudo tail -f /var/log/nginx/error.log

Verify configuration syntax: 

sudo nginx -t

docs.title: Certificate Issues
docs.text:
Check Certbot logs: 

sudo tail -f /var/log/letsencrypt/letsencrypt.log

Verify domain DNS is pointing to your server: 

nslookup your-domain.com

docs.title: 502 Bad Gateway Error
docs.text:
Ensure HCPI is running: 

sudo systemctl status hcpi

Check HCPI logs: 

tail -f /opt/hcpi/log/hcpi.log

docs.title: Connection Timeout
docs.text:
Check firewall rules: 

sudo ufw status

Verify Nginx is listening on ports 80 and 443: 

sudo netstat -tlnp | grep nginx

docs.title: Enable Gzip Compression
docs.text:
Add to your Nginx configuration inside the server block:

gzip on;
gzip_types text/plain text/css application/json application/javascript text/xml application/xml;
gzip_min_length 1000;

docs.title: Enable Caching for Static Files
docs.text:
Add inside the server block:

location ~* \.(js|css|png|jpg|jpeg|gif|ico|svg|woff|woff2|ttf|eot)$ {
    proxy_pass http://127.0.0.1:9201;
    expires 1y;
    add_header Cache-Control "public, immutable";
}

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text:
Protect against abuse by adding rate limiting:

# Add this outside the server block
limit_req_zone $binary_remote_addr zone=hcpi:10m rate=10r/s;

# Add this inside the server block
location / {
    limit_req zone=hcpi burst=20 nodelay;
    # ... rest of proxy configuration ...
}

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Keep Software Updated: Regularly update Nginx, Certbot, and the OS
  2. Monitor Logs: Review Nginx and HCPI logs regularly
  3. Use Strong SSL Configuration: Keep SSL protocols and ciphers up to date
  4. Implement Fail2ban: Protect against brute force attacks
  5. Regular Backups: Back up your Nginx configuration and SSL certificates

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Set up regular database backups
  • Configure monitoring and alerting
  • Implement log rotation for Nginx and HCPI logs
  • Consider setting up a CDN for static assets
  • Review and harden server security settings
